did.head: Collection Summary
did.abstract: Hubbell Trading Post records pertain to vendor files, business materials, and personal and business correspondence.

repository.label: Repository:
repository.corpname: University of Arizona Libraries, Special Collections

prefercite.head: Credit Line
prefercite.p: Hubbell Trading Post papers(AZ 375). Special Collections, University of Arizona Libraries.

bioghist.head: Historical Note
bioghist.p: Located at Ganado, Arizona, on the Navajo Reservation; started by John Lorenzo Hubbell in 1876. It was later operated by family members; the last was his daughter-in-law Dorothy Smith Hubbell. She ran it as a museum until the National Park Service took responsibility for it as a National Historic Site, in 1967. Thirty-five other stores were established throughout the Southwest by John Lorenzo Hubbell and his family, and some of their records are included here. In addition to supplying the local Native Americans with needed goods, the Hubbell enterprise is significant for its promotion and national marketing of Navajo rugs and silverwork, as well as Hopi pottery and baskets.

arrangement.head: Organization
arrangement.p: This collection is organized into nine Sub-groups

list.item: Sub-group IX: Advertisements, Price Lists, and Catalogs

scopecontent.head: Scope and Content Note
scopecontent.p: The bulk of this collection consists of vendor files, business materials, and correspondence. The correspondence series are comprised of incoming, outgoing, and Indian letters. Business correspondence includes government organizations, particularly the Republican party; Indian organizations, such as the Indian Arts and Crafts Board; and business organizations that bought Indian goods, notably Fred Harvey. Personal correspondence included that of artists and writers, such as Laura Adams Armer and Elbridge Ayer Burbank, employees, friends, local Navajo and Hopi individuals, and family members. Correspondence, as well as personal papers, are present for John Lorenzo Hubbell, his daughters Barbara H. Goodman and Adele H. Parker, his sons Roman Hubbell and Lorenzo Hubbell, Jr., and their spouses and children.

Off-post and intra-post vendor series contain the following: orders, invoices, consignment lists, freight bills, packing sips, statements of charges, receipts, loan notes, tax statements, rental notices, and credit memos. Long-term vendor relations are with the Babbitt Brothers Co., C.N. Cotton Co., and Gallup Mercantile.

The Business series are comprised of daily, summary, and Indian records; included are daybooks, cashbooks, individual accounts, and inventories. As with the intra-post vendor series, most of the Hubbell stores are represented, but Ganado, Winslow, and Oraibi have the most extensive records.

Legal items encompass maps, mortgages, titles, leases, estate and court records, and trading post licenses. Within the banking materials are statements, deposits, overdrafts, credits, World War II rationing accounts, and cancelled checks from numerous banks in Arizona, New Mexico, and California.
Other items in the collection are insurance company policies, post office records, sales books, and national store catalogs.

item.corpname: United States -- Indian Arts and Crafts Board

item.geogname: Hubbell Trading Post National Historic Site (Ganado, Ariz.) -- Archives

separatedmaterial.head: Separated Material
separatedmaterial.p: Seventy boxes of sales slips were returned to the Hubbell Trading Post at Ganado, Arizona. Only a sample of the sales books have been processed. Seventy boxes of sales books are in storage.

scopecontent.p: Contains all correspondence not originating at a Hubbell-owned/operated trading post or store. Family members who were not immediate to J.L. Hubbell family members or who had no connection with a Hubbell-owned/operated trading post or store are also included here. Occasionally bills, sales slips, etc., when attached to the original letter, will be found here. Occasionally company form letters (even, though rarely, not specifically addressed to a Hubbell, Hubbell employee or Hubbell trading post) will be found here. Correspondence from a specific person may include such odds and ends as newspaper clippings about that person, notices or reviews of an author's books, notices of a painter's gallery shows, programs in which an individual takes part, articles or other writings, etc.; correspondence from a company may include advertising matter and other miscellaneous items.

Cameron, Ralph file contains considerable material related to post offices. Cancelograph Co. file contains all materials related to this company and J.L. Hubbell's involvement with it (company stocks, corporate organization, announcement of stockholders' meetings, etc.).

Contains all official correspondence from various Indian agencies and schools and all official correspondence from other governmental departments, bureaus, etc. which relates to Indians or Indian trading posts. Correspondence from the Navajo tribe--as distinct from federal tribal agencies--is found under that heading (box 62).

Contains all official correspondence from various Indian agencies and schools and all official correspondence from other governmental departments, bureaus, etc. which relates to Indians or Indian trading posts. Correspondence from the Navajo tribe--as distinct from federal tribal agencies--is found under that heading (box 62).

Contains all official correspondence from various Indian agencies and schools and all official correspondence from other governmental departments, bureaus, etc. which relates to Indians or Indian trading posts. Correspondence from the Navajo tribe--as distinct from federal tribal agencies--is found under that heading (box 62).

Contains official correspondence from all county, state, and national Republican Party organizations; includes most correspondence of J.L. Hubbell as chairman of the Arizona Central Committee (but not his personal/business correspondence; this will be found in the next series).

did.unittitle: Hubbell Papers: correspondence between Dorothy S. Hubbell, Park Service officials and University of Arizona personnel concerning the University's becoming a repository for the Papers.

scopecontent.p: Contains all business correspondence of the Hubbell-owned/operated trading posts or stores. Contains the personal correspondence of the immediate members of the J.L. Hubbell family: Barbara H. Goodman, Adele H. Goodman, Roman Hubbell, and Lorenzo Hubbell, Jr., and their wives/husbands and children. Also contains personal correspondence for all others (both family and non-family) who worked for the Hubbells. Many persons will be found both in this and in the previous series.

scopecontent.p: Contains correspondence, mostly from local (Navajo or Hopi) individuals, addresses directly to a Hubbell or Hubbell employee, or addressed to a family member or the correspondent but sent to a Hubbell or Hubbell employee to be read to that family member. Indians who operated their own trading posts or other business will not be found here. Indians who worked in a Hubbell trading post or store will not be found here. For any given individual, all three series should be consulted.

This group is concerned with the exchange of goods or services between the Hubbells and individuals or companies or with the exchange of goods and services within the Hubbell business. Within this group will be found such things as orders, invoices, consignment lists, freight bills, packing slips, statements of charges, receipts, notes (loans), tax assessments/statements, rental notices, etc.

Contains all orders, invoices, freight bills, statements, etc. between an individual or company and the Hubbell business. The flow of goods or services may be in either direction or both; ie. an order by the Hubbells for goods or services from a person or company, or an order by a person or company for goods or services from the Hubbells, or a combination of the two. The transaction will be under the name of the individual or company, whether customer or supplier (vendor), in an alphabetical sequence.
Indian file contains all reservation agency business dealings with the Hubbells. It is divided into Hopi, Navajo, and other Indians.

Contains all orders, charges, credit memos, statements, wholesale/retail invoices, etc. concerned with the exchange of goods between one Hubbell post/store and another. The arrangement is alphabetical by post of origin; ie. if an order is from Pinon to Winslow it would be filed under Pinon but the statement of charges is from Winslow and would be found under Winslow.

Sub-group III: Business Books and Records, 1882-1967

scopecontent.p: Contains all the books and records in which the ordinary flow of business is accounted for on a day-to-day basis: daybooks, cashbooks, individual accounts (ledgers, ledger sheets), journals, daily sheets, etc.

scopecontent.p: Contains a wide range of materials concerned with a general accounting of the business on a monthly, quarterly, yearly basis (inventories, financial statements, profit and loss, accounts payable/receivable, etc.).

scopecontent.p: This is a miscellany and contains all the various kinds of records relating to Indians that could not consistently be located in previous series. Included here also are personal Indian materials.

Personal materials: schools/students (report cards, etc), accounting of deposits into interest accounts with Hubbells; miscellaneous personal items (veterans' training, railroad retirement board applications for benefits, appointments as judges of Indian courts, General Accounting Office settlements of claims, divorce notices, etc).
